awd_titl_txt: CRCNS Research Proposal: US-German Collaboration: Influencing Brain Rhythms for Boosting Memory Consolidation
awd_abstract_narration:
This study aims to understand the neural mechanisms of sleep, with the goal to optimally apply external stimulation techniques for enhancing the efficacy of deep sleep. In the industrial societies the level of sleep is on a record low level and more and more people suffer from poor sleep. Deep sleep constitutes a major part of the night, and a number of studies have shown that efficient and healthy deep sleep is important not only for cognitive performance and learning, but also for strengthening the immune system, healthy functioning of the metabolic system, and is even crucial for children with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Syndrome (ADHS). The promise of stimulation techniques is that they can be applied non-invasively with a potentially broad range of applications and minimal side effects, not only in clinical settings but even at home, and at a low cost. 

During sleep, the brain is not at rest but rather in an "off-line" state, where it strengthens and stabilizes newly encoded information to maintain it for the long-term in a process of systems consolidation. There is increasing evidence that the interplay of the major electrical brain rhythms during deep sleep is necessary for the transfer of information into long-term memory. The ultimate goals of this research project are (a) to understand the neuronal processes that allow to boost these endogenous brain rhythms by external stimulation during sleep, acoustically and electrically, and (b) to study these interventions to optimize the strengthening and coordination of sleep rhythms to improve memory and learning. The approach includes combinations of auditory stimulation and optogenetic experiments in rodents, auditory stimulation combined with transcranial direct current stimulation in humans and large-scale computer brain models of sleep and wake states, simulating new task learning and memory consolidation and the effects of various stimulation techniques. The project will suggest new approaches for improving memory, perception, and sleep both in healthy subjects and in patients with mental and sleep disorders such as schizophrenia, Alzheimer's disease, or substance use disorders.

This award is co-funded by the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering. A companion project is being funded by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research, Germany (BMBF).

por.por_cntn:
Sleep is not just a rest period for the brain; it is an active 'off-line' state where recent information is processed for long-term retention. This systems consolidation phase is key, as it refines new information to help form explicit knowledge and insights. Recent studies highlight the importance of synchronized brain activities during sleep - cortical slow oscillations (SO, 0.2-1Hz), thalamic spindles (7-15Hz), and hippocampal sharp wave-ripples (80-180Hz) - in transferring information into long-term memory. A pivotal discovery is that these natural brain rhythms can be modulated by external stimuli during deep sleep, thereby potentially improving learning outcomes.

Our research sought to uncover how memory consolidation occurs during sleep and to disclose which electrophysiological activity affecting consolidation is modulated by sensory stimulation. Using biophysically realistic brain models, we predicted that closed-loop stimulation timed with the Down to Up state transition during sleep slow oscillations maximizes synaptic strengthening and memory recall after sleep (see Fig. 1). When multiple memories are formed during wakefulness, stimulation linked to specific memories can aid in their consolidation.

In vivo experiments, involving recordings and behavioral tests on mice with acoustic stimulation timed to different sleep slow oscillation phases, confirmed our model's predictions. Stimulation at 180 ms post-Down state peak  - during the early phase of the Up state - significantly enhanced memory retention compared to other stimulation phases, aligning with our hypotheses (see Fig. 2). In this set-up significant performance enhancement over sham was however not found. Across all phases, stimulation triggered an immediate ripple activity spike, followed by suppression of hippocampal sharp wave-ripples and prolonged dampening of thalamo-cortical spindle activity. Notably, 180 ms stimulation improved the peak correlation between slow oscillations and ripples compared to control (see Fig. 3), suggesting a mechanism where closed-loop acoustic stimulation modulates memory consolidation by altering the coupling of sleep electrical activities.

By further integrating hippocampal inputs, we investigated a dual memory system that involves interactions between the hippocampus (for new memory storage) and the cortex (for permanent memory storage) during sleep, aiming to minimize interference between new and established memories. We discovered that delivering hippocampal sharp wave-ripples near the Down to Up state transition biases memory replay toward recent memories in the early phase of slow waves, while replay during the late phase tends to favor older memories. This indicates that precisely timed hippocampal input can incorporate new memories into the cortex without disrupting older ones by interleaving the replay of memories within individual Up states.

The broader impacts of our project include training for graduate students and postdocs, with an emphasis on women and underrepresented minorities such as Hispanic and African-American students. We also organized annual workshops on sleep and memory consolidation, drawing over 100 participants from students to faculty. The models developed in this project are available online. Some models are also shared via the Neuroscience Gateway and are hosted by Cybershuttle, which is part of an NSF-funded project to develop cyberinfrastructure services.

Besides its impact on neuroscience research, our work has also influenced the fields of machine learning and artificial intelligence by leading to the development of a sleep replay consolidation (SRC) algorithm for artificial neural networks. The SRC algorithm supports continuous learning, as well as the transfer and generalization of knowledge. Moreover, our findings have implications in the physical sciences, especially in exploring how various forms of stimulation, such as electrical or auditory, affect brain activity. This research could pave the way for new, both non-invasive and invasive, techniques for improving memory and learning.
